questions.text: Which of the following features is not true about necroptosis?

choices.text: It is a form of programmed cell death

questions.solution:
Caspase activation does not occur in necroptosis. It is a caspase-independent form of programmed cell death.

Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis (which is normally an unprogrammed process). Though the activation of this pathway is similar to apoptosis, there is no activation of caspases, which is an important part of apoptosis.

Necroptosis is triggered by the activation of TNFR1 by TNF-α. This induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and the formation of a necrosome. The necrosome reduces cellular ATP levels.

Necroptosis occurs in the following conditions:

  • Pathological - ischemic brain injury, neurodegenerative diseases, viral infections
  • Physiological - formation of the mammalian bone growth plate

The following table lists the differences between apoptosis and necroptosis:

Feature Apoptosis Necroptosis
Induction stimuli Oxidative stress, death receptor ligands, chemotherapy Viral or chemical exposure, radiation, endogenous or pathological factors
Morphological changes                   Nuclear pyknosis, membrane blebbing, generation of apoptotic bodies Swelling of cells and organelles, loss of membrane integrity
Molecular changes Cleavage of caspases, DNA fragmentation Acidosis, random DNA degradation, release of cellular proteins
Clearance Apoptotic bodies phagocytosed by neighboring cells and macrophages Necrotic cells ingested by macrophages, significant inflammation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic dyspepsia underwent upper GI endoscopy. The biopsy findings are shown below. What is the special stain that has been used?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following finding on her finger. She says that she cut her finger while chopping vegetables 2 weeks ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and clinical findings are suggestive of exuberant granulation.

It is a deviation in wound healing where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization. It is also known as proud flesh.

questions.text: An 18-year-old student is referred by his ophthalmologist for further evaluation after detecting ectopia lentis, which had resulted in visual difficulties. The patient is very tall, with long limbs and long, slender, spiderlike fingers. His chest has a 'caved-in' appearance, and he also has a modest degree of scoliosis. A midsystolic click is heard, and an echocardiogram reveals mitral valve prolapse. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations of the fibrillin gene on chromosome 15. It is a frequent cause of ectopia lentis.

Patients are tall and thin, with notably long limbs and digits. An anterior chest deformity known as pectus excavatum is sometimes seen, and vertebral abnormalities include scoliosis and lordosis. In addition, a high-arched palate and crowding of the teeth may occur.

Cardiovascular complications include mitral valve prolapse and mitral regurgitation. Cystic medial necrosis can lead to the dilation of the aortic root and aortic regurgitation. Life-threatening complications are aortic aneurysm and aortic dissection.

questions.text: Which of the following trinucleotides is involved in the pathogenesis of Huntington disease?
questions.solution:
• Huntington disease (HD) is the prototype of the polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases.
  • The gene for HD, HTT, located on chromosome 4p16.3, encodes a 348-kD protein known as huntingtin.
  • In the first exon of the gene, there is a stretch of CAG repeats that encodes a polyglutamine region near the N-terminus of the protein.
  • Normal HTT genes contain six to 35 copies of the repeat; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level, it is associated with disease.
  • There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats tend to be associated with earlier onset.
  • Repeat expansions occur during spermatogenesis, so that paternal transmission is associated with early onset in the next generation, a phenomenon termed anticipation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a pearly papule over the face containing prominent dilated subepidermal blood vessels and surface ulceration. A histological picture of the tumor is shown below. All are true about the tumor except:

choices.text: Incidence is increased in xeroderma pigmentosum
Presence of multiple such tumors is seen in Gorlin syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare.

It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.

BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers). Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with peripheral palisading and retraction cleft.

It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling.

Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles.

The image below shows the histopathology of BCC.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological picture of her lung is shown below.  What is the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis.

Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a failed endotracheal intubation. 

The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include:

  • Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)
  • Gastric pH < 2.5

Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of:

  • Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation
  • H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine 
  • Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction

Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and plugs of loose connective tissue on histology.

Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology.

Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.

questions.text: What is frustrated phagocytosis?

choices.text: Release of lysosomal contents due to damaged membrane
Engulfment of infectious pathogens and degradation by phagolysosome
Release of lysosomal enzymes when phagocytes cannot engulf targets

questions.solution:
The term frustrated phagocytosis refers to the release of large amounts of lysosomal contents into the external environment due the inability of the phagocytes to engulf.

When immune complexes are deposited on relatively flat immovable surfaces, the phagocytes are unable to surround and ingest them. In this case, the activation signals lead to an uncontrolled release of the lysosomal contents, despite lack of phagocytosis. This is known as frustrated phagocytosis. 

Other processes may lead to the release of lysosomal contents into the external environment:

  • Controlled secretion of granule contents - normal response of activated leukocytes
  • Damage to the phagolysosome membrane by certain phagocytosed substances like urate crystals

questions.text: The accumulation of aggregates of the protein ______ is associated with Parkinson disease and multiple system atrophy.
questions.solution:
The pathologic process that is common across most of the neurodegenerative diseases is the accumulation of protein aggregates, which is a morphologic hallmark of the disease.

The protein aggregates are recognized histologically as inclusions, which often are the diagnostic hallmark of the disease.

The basis for aggregation varies from one disease to another.

It may be directly related to an intrinsic feature of a mutated protein (e.g., expanded polyglutamine repeats in Huntington disease), an intrinsic feature of a peptide derived from a larger precursor protein (e.g., Aβ in Alzheimer disease), or an unexplained alteration of a normal cellular protein (e.g., α-synuclein in sporadic Parkinson disease).

Proteins Disease with Inclusion
Aβ Alzheimer disease
Tau

Alzheimer disease

Frontotemporal degeneration

Parkinson's disease(with LRKK2 mutation)

Progressive supranuclear palsy

Corticobasal degeneration
TPD-43

Frontotemporal degeneration

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
FUS

Frontotemporal degeneration

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
α- synuclein

questions.text: A patient who was admitted for blood transfusion developed transfusion-related acute lung injury. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Pre-existing lung diseases are a risk factor
Incidence with platelet transfusion is more than that with whole blood
Symptoms develop after 2 days of transfusion
Subsequent transfusions from the same donor increases the incidence

questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after the transfusion. It occurs within 6 hours, and not after 2 days following transfusion.

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The incidence of TRALI is low (1 per 10,000 transfusions). However, it may occur more frequently in patients with preexisting lung disease.  

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI can occur in transfusions with all plasma-containing blood products. However, it is more likely to occur following the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets. This is because these products contain high levels of donor antibodies.  

Note: TRALI is important to recognize because donor products that induce complications in one patient are much more likely to do so in a second. Indeed, recent measures to exclude multiparous women from plasma donation have resulted in reduced incidence of TRALI.

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is ________
questions.solution:
The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy. 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

Other postoperative problems include infection and malignancies, especially Epstein–Barr virus-associated B-cell lymphomas.

The image given below shows allograft arteriopathy. There is severe diffuse concentric intimal thickening producing critical stenosis. The internal elastic lamina and media are intact (Movat pentachrome stain, elastin black)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
While actin belongs to a separate class of cytoskeletal proteins called microfilaments, the other three (lamin, vimentin, and desmin) belong to the group of intermediate filaments.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins, namely, microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

Cytoskeletal proteins:

1. Actin microfilaments:

  • These are 5- to 9-nm diameter fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin). The G-actin monomers noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments

  • These are 10-nm diameter fibrils that include family of related proteins sharing common structural and sequence features. Individual types have characteristic tissue-specific patterns of expression that can be useful for assigning a cell of origin for poorly differentiated tumors.
  • These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not usually actively reorganize like actin and microtubules. They impart tensile strength and allow cells to bear mechanical stress.
Type of intermediate filament (IF) protein Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. The nuclear membrane lamins are responsible for maintaining nuclear morphology and nuclear transcription. Mutations In lamin proteins is associated with certain disorders such as muscular dystrophy and progeria.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts and endothelial cells)
Desmin These proteins are mainly present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are present in the axons of neurons and impart strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein These are present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins. There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair keratin).

 

3. Microtubules: These are 25-nm-thick fibrils formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin and beta-tubulin.  These dimers polymerize such that the beta-subunit of one dimer combines with the alpha-subunit of another dimer. The polymerization of these dimers leads to the formation of protofilament, where one end of it has a beta-subunit exposed (designated as + end), while the other end has an alpha-subunit exposed (designated as – end). The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smear shows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells.

Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that are home to the skin.

Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goes into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells.

In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a histiocytic neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Rosai–Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy.

WHO classification of histiocytic/ hematolymphoid neoplasm 2016 includes the following:

  • Histiocytic sarcoma
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Langerhans cell sarcoma
  • Indeterminate dendritic cell tumour
  • lnterdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma
  • Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma
  • Fibroblastic reticular cell tumour
  • Disseminated juvenile xanthogranuloma
  • Erdheim–Chester disease

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have megaloblastic anaemia. Which of the following will not be helpful in differentiating vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Increased serum homocysteine levels are common to both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. Hence, it cannot be used to differentiate between them.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma is chronic hepatitis B virus infection. More than 85% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma occur in countries with high rates of chronic hepatitis B virus infection.

Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma are:

  • Hepatitis B virus
  • Hepatitis C virus 
  • Alcohol
  • Aflatoxin
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Tyrosinemia
  • Smoking

Activation of β-catenin and inactivation of p53 are the two most common early mutational events seen in hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by:
questions.solution:
Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted:

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: On which chromosome are HLA genes located?
questions.solution:
The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on a short arm of chromosome 6 (6p).

The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The HLA system is highly polymorphic. Each individual’s HLA alleles differ from the other. It has to be checked before organ transplantation.

questions.text: Who among the following patients is at increased risk for developing amyloidosis?

choices.text: A patient with maturity-onset diabetes of the young
A 15-year-old diabetic boy who is on insulin therapy
A 50-year-old diabetic patient with insulin resistance
A patient with autosomal dominant non-insulin dependent form of diabetes

questions.solution:
Older individuals with insulin resistance are likely to have type 2 diabetes mellitus. These patients are at increased risk of developing amyloidosis. 

Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as:

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
  • Islet tumors of the pancreas
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach
  • Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Endoscopy of a patient with chronic upper gastrointestinal bleeding showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The endoscopy findings of the watermelon stomach are suggestive of gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE).

In GAVE, endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon. GAVE is responsible for 4% of non-variceal upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Dieulafoy lesion is a non-stress-related cause of GI bleeding. It is due to a submucosal artery that does not branch properly within the wall of the stomach. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which serum protein is the major component of senile cardiac amyloid deposits?
questions.solution:
Transthyretin is the major component of senile cardiac amyloid deposits. It is a normal serum protein synthesized in the liver that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein.

Amyloidosis of the heart can develop as a consequence of systemic amyloidosis or it may be localized. This is particularly seen in the elderly (senile cardiac amyloidosis). It has a far better prognosis than systemic amyloidosis.

Presentation of cardiac amyloidosis:

  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy- most common
  • Asymptomatic
  • Dilation
  • Arrhythmias
  • Ischemic disease
  • Valvular disease.

The chambers are usually of normal size, but can be dilated and have thickened walls. Small, semitranslucent nodules resembling drips of wax may be seen on the atrial endocardial surface, particularly on the left.

Histologically, hyaline eosinophilic deposits of amyloid are found in:

  • Interstitium
  • Conduction tissue
  • Valves, endocardium
  • Pericardium
  • Small intramural coronary arteries.

The image given shows an endomyocardial biopsy of a patient with cardiac amyloidosis stained as follows: A) Congo red only, B) Apple-green birefringence under polarized light

questions.text: Which form of systemic vasculitis is most likely to present with an orbital pseudotumor?
questions.solution: Granulomatosis with polyangitis (Wegener granulomatosis) can lead to orbital pseudotumor and scleritis. This pseudotumor can cause proptosis and vision loss if blood circulation to the eye is compromised by the retrobulbar mass.

questions.text: Which of the following is also called marble bone disease?
questions.solution:
Albers-Schönberg disease or osteopetrosis is also known as marble bone disease.

The term osteopetrosis reflects the stone-like quality of the bones. The bones are abnormally brittle and fracture easily, like a piece of chalk. It occurs due to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis because of impaired formation or function of osteoclasts.

Note: Osteogenesis imperfecta is also called brittle bone disease. Paget's disease is also called osteitis deformans; it presents with mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.

questions.text: In which condition is Alzheimer type II astrocyte seen?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer type II astrocyte is seen in hepatic encephelopathy.

Alzheimer type II astrocyte (unrelated to Alzheimer disease but first described by the same individual):

  • It is a grey-matter cell with a large nucleus, pale-­staining central chromatin, an intranuclear glycogen droplet, and a prominent nuclear membrane and nucleolus.
  • It is mainly seen in individuals with long-­standing hyperammonemia due to chronic liver disease, Wilson disease, or hereditary metabolic disorders of the urea cycle.
  • In gliosis, astrocytes are called gemistocytic astrocytes.
  • In hepatic encephalopathy, astrocytes with enlarged nuclei and minimal reactive cytoplasm (known as Alzheimer type II cells) appear in the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and other subcortical gray-matter regions.

questions.text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. 

It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.

Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.

Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.

Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

It induces alternatively activated macrophages. This results in tissue repair and the resolution of inflammation.

The following are anti-inflammatory cytokines:

  • IL-4
  • IL-10
  • IL-13
  • TGF-β
  • Lipoxins

Lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting leukocyte recruitment. They inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia presents with a one-day history of bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleed, and purpuric rash. Investigations done are given below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?

Hb: 6.4 gm/dL

TLC: 26,500 cells/mm3

Platelet: 35,000 mm3

Prothrombin time: 20 sec with a control of 13 sec

Partial thromboplastin time: 50 sec

Fibrinogen: 10 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient shows features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It is most likely to be associated with acute myeloid leukemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia. The pathogenesis behind this is t(15,17) or PML-RARA fusion gene.

Option A: Inversion 16 is seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia or AML - M4. 

Option B: t(8;21) is seen in AML with differentiation or AML - M2.

Option C: Inversion 3 is seen in AML - M7 (megakaryoblastic) which shows normal or increased platelet count. It has a poor prognosis.

questions.text: Hyperviscosity symptoms in patients with multiple myeloma occur due to which of the following types of M protein?
questions.solution:
Symptoms related to hyperviscosity in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype.

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein. Less commonly, it also occurs in multiple myeloma (with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases.

Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. Symptoms are not seen at <4, and hyperviscosity syndrome typically requires a viscosity of >5 units.

Clinical features include:

  • Visual impairment
  • Neurologic problems
  • Bleeding
  • Cryoglobulinemia

questions.text: In which of the following conditions are Arbiskov cells seen?
questions.solution:
Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma.

Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a hematopoietic stem cell tumor, where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites. Orbit is one of the most common sites of occurrences in pediatric population. It is seen in AML - M2 most commonly. Other conditions associated are myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes. 

The image given below shows Arbiskov cells in chloroma.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcers underwent an upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy was stained with a special stain as shown in the image. Identify the special stain used.
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the Helicobacter pylori bacilli.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin-Starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

The image given below is GI biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

The below image is a Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

questions.text: The genetic profile of malignant mixed Müllerian tumors resembles that of:
questions.solution:
Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profile closely resembles endometrial carcinomas.

They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual genetic alterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs.

MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. The mesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adipose tissue, and bone).

It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a poor outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies would you not expect to see in a patient with autoimmune hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Anti-TIF1γ antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1γ antibodies are found in patients with dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: Infection with which of the following organisms would produce an inflammatory infiltrate with neutrophilic predominance beyond 48 hours?
questions.solution:
In Pseudomonas infection, the inflammatory infiltrate has a neutrophilic predominance for several days.

Normally, in acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate the inflammatory infiltrate during the first 6 to 24 hours. However, they are short-lived, and disappear within 24 to 48 hours, following which they are replaced by monocytes.

Monocytes survive longer and also proliferate in the tissues. Thus, they become the dominant population in prolonged inflammatory reactions.

The exceptions to this pattern include:

  1. Pseudomonas infections - neutrophilic dominance in the infiltrate for several days
  2. Viral infections - lymphocytes are the initial cells
  3. Allergic reactions - eosinophils are the main cell type
  4. Some types of hypersensitivity - dominated by activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells

questions.text: A routine urine examination of a 46-year-old woman shows thorn-apple crystals. Past history is significant for constipation and longstanding use of laxatives. What is the likely composition of these crystals?
questions.solution:
Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregular projections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: What is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children?
questions.solution:
The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma.

The paratesticular region is an extratesticular anatomical area, which includes the contents:

  • Spermatic cord,
  • Testicular tunics,
  • Epididymis 
  • Vestigial remnants, such as the appendices epididymis and testis.

The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults is liposarcoma.

The most common benign paratesticular tumor is an adenomatoid tumor.

The most common paratesticular mesenchymal tumor is a lipoma.

questions.text: Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are called:
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are Brenner tumors or transitional cell tumors.

Transitional cell tumors are a rare type of ovarian epithelial tumor. They contain neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium and are usually benign. They are often detected incidentally and even when large they do not produce any symptoms.

Microscopy features include fibrous stroma, with sharply demarcated nests of urothelial cells, often with mucinous glands in their center, called Walthard cell rests, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option B- Krukenberg tumor is a bilateral metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site in the gastrointestinal tract. Microscopically, it is characterized by the appearance of mucin-secreting signet-ring cells in the tissue of the ovary.

Option C- Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor that commonly produces masculinization or defeminization. These tumors showed a range of  differentiation:

 - Well-differentiated tumors show tubules composed of Sertoli cells or Leydig cells interspersed with stroma
 - Intermediate forms show immature tubules with large eosinophilic Leydig cell
 - Poorly differentiated show sarcomatous pattern

Option D- Hilus cell tumors or pure Leydig cell tumors are also sex cord-stromal tumors. They are rare and unilateral tumors. Large lipid-laden Leydig cells with distinct borders and characteristic rod-shaped cytoplasmic structures called Reinke crystalloids are present in these tumors. Females with hilus cell tumors usually have features of masculinization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer’s disease is associated with mutations in chromosomes 1, 14, 19, and 21.

  • APP gene on chromosome 21
    • Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome): Extra dose of the APP gene on chromosome 21 is the initiating cause of AD in adult Down’s syndrome and results in excess cerebral amyloid production. 
    • Families with early-onset familial AD (FAD) have point mutations in APP.
  • Presenilin-1 (PS-1) is on chromosome 14 and encodes a protein called S182.
  • Presenilin-2 (PS-2) is on chromosome 1 and encodes a protein called STM2.
    • PS-1 is involved in the cleavage of APP at the γ secretase site and mutations in either gene (PS-1 or APP) may disturb γ-secretase cleavage. 
    • Mutations in PS-1 are the most common cause of early-onset FAD (40–70% of all cases).
    • Mutations in PS-1 tend to produce AD with an earlier age of onset (mean onset 45 years) and a shorter, more rapidly progressive course (mean duration 6–7 years) than the disease caused by mutations in PS-2 (mean onset 53 years; duration 11 years).
  • Apo ε gene on chromosome 19: Three alleles: ε2, ε3, and ε4. The Apo ε4 allele confers increased risk of AD in the general population, including sporadic and late-onset familial forms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. MRI was done and showed the presence of bilateral acoustic schwannomas. Which protein involved in cytoskeletal stability is mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and MRI findings are suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). Merlin protein is mutated in NF-2, sporadic schwannomas, and meningiomas.

Cells lacking Merlin do not establish stable cell-to-cell junctions. They are insensitive to normal growth arrest signals generated by cell-to-cell contact.

questions.text: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin.

It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen.

This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a combination of regeneration and scarring.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman has been diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry staining of a tissue biopsy specimen of this patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: It is not associated with tP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), and negative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal A molecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel.

Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR–positive breast cancer cells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and hence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes. 

Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations. 

Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents like tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2. 

The following image shows ER/ PR/ Her-2 positivity:

Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations are associated with triple-negative tumors as well.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Consider the following subjects. Subject 1 is a 12-year-old girl who has attained puberty. Subject 2 is a 28-year-old pregnant lady. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, statement C is false. Subject 1 will not have uterine hyperplasia.

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia:

  • Puberty:
    • Breast: Both hypertrophy (enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells) and hyperplasia (proliferation of the glandular epithelium) in equal proportions
    • No changes occur in the uterus
  • Pregnancy:
    • Breast: Both hypertrophy and hyperplasia in equal proportions
    • Uterus: Mainly hypertrophy (stretch‐induced myometrial hypertrophy) and also minor hyperplasia (of smooth muscle cells in the myometrium).
  • Lactation:
    • Breast: Only hypertrophy

The amount of chemotherapy-induced necrosis is an important prognostic finding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. 

Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.

Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.

On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma.

Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple, small, pink nodular growths on the temples. A biopsy from the lesion showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor). 

Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy epilation of the scalp. 

The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic‐like masses - a jigsaw appearance. Malignant transformation is very rare.

Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors:

  • Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma
  • Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma
  • Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenomas
  • Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmomas

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:

questions.text: A patient with gastric carcinoma develops proximal muscle weakness. Biopsy findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and juvenile dermatomyositis.

It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease. Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition.

It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is most common in India.

The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and young adults. It has an excellent prognosis.

Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a male predominance.

The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cells

questions.text: Bone marrow biopsy of a normal adult is given below. What is the ratio of structures marked A and B?
questions.solution:
The structures marked A are fat cells and B are hematopoietic elements. The normal ratio of fat cells to hematopoietic elements in a normal adult is 1:1. 

In hypoplastic states (like aplastic anemia), the proportion of fat cells is greatly increased (increased fat to cell ratio).

Conversely, fat cells often disappear in conditions like hematopoietic tumors and in diseases with compensatory hyperplasias (like hemolytic anemias) and neoplastic proliferations such as leukemias (decreased fat-to-cell ratio).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease. Mitral stenosis is the most common lesion in rheumatic heart disease. 

In rheumatic mitral stenosis, calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures create fish mouth or buttonhole stenosis. Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1.

The most common causes of various valvular diseases are:

  • Aortic stenosis (AS) - calcification due to normal aging or congenitally bicuspid aortic valves
  • Aortic regurgitation (AR) - dilatation of the ascending aorta, often secondary to hypertension and/or aging
  • Mitral regurgitation (MR) - myxomatous degeneration (mitral valve prolapse)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with hemoptysis and loss of weight. Chest radiograph shows multiple canon-ball metastases. Physical examination revealed no palpable mass. The serum HCG level is raised, but no change in AFP and CEA  levels. Biopsy from the lung lesion reveals the following finding. What is the most likely primary tumor?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario and image showing cytotrophoblasts and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts in a hemorrhagic background, the most likely primary tumor appears to be choriocarcinoma.

The syncytiotrophoblasts secrete β-hCG, at levels that serve as important serological markers.

Pure choriocarcinoma, although rare, is the most aggressive non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). It often does not cause any testicular enlargement; instead, it spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung(cannon-ball metastases) and liver and a poor prognosis.

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with migratory arthralgia and a malar skin rash that is exacerbated by sun exposure. Her urinalysis shows moderate proteinuria and red blood cell casts and she had leucopenia. Serum auto-antibodies with high specificity for this patient’s condition react with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The autoantibodies (anti-ds-DNA) react with double-stranded DNA.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs). The injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and the binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

Option A: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are specific for primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option B: Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self-IgG. It is found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and other collagen tissue disorders.

Option C: Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with CREST syndrome.

questions.text: Weibel-Palade bodies are present in_______.
questions.solution: Weibel–Palade bodies are the storage granules of endothelial cells. They store and release two principal molecules, von Willebrand factor and P-selectin, and thus play a dual role in hemostasis and inflammation.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: Werner syndrome is _______.
questions.solution:
Patients with Werner syndrome show premature aging. The defective gene product is DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication, repair, and other functions that require DNA unwinding. The defect causes the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

Option d:

Sirtuins are NAD-dependent protein deacetylases that function to adapt bodily functions to various environmental stresses. So, a defective sirtuin can lead to cellular aging. 

Note:

Werner syndrome should not be confused with Wermer syndrome, i.e. multiple endocrine neoplasias, type 1, a rare heritable disorder characterized by abnormalities involving the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.

The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³.

It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.

  • Total blood count:
    • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. 
    • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
    • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells.
  • Peripheral smear:
    • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
    • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
    • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
    • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)
  • Lymph node biopsy:
    • Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates
    • Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.

The chromosomal defects:

  • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
  • Deletion of 11q
  • Trisomy 12q
  • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.text: Which of the following is not an integrin molecule?
questions.solution:
CD 31 or platelet endothelial cell-adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM-1) is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. It is not an integrin molecule.

The various endothelial and leukocyte adhesion molecules include:

  • Selectin family - mediates initial rolling interactions between leukocytes and endothelium
  • Integrin family - 
    • Involved in migration and firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium
    • Includes LFA-1, MAC-1, and VLA-4
  • Immunoglobulin family -
    • PECAM (CD31) - most important adhesion molecule for diapedesis
    • ICAM-1 - binds to β2 integrins on leukocytes

questions.text: The function of which of the following factors is not screened by the partial thromboplastin time assay?
questions.solution:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.

The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.

In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.

questions.text: A patient with generalized lymphadenopathy and Pel-Ebstein fever is diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is a characteristic finding seen in this condition?

choices.text: Pain in nodes relieved by alcohol
Pain in nodes aggravated by alcohol

questions.solution:
In the case of Hodgkin's Lymphoma, the pain in the lymph nodes aggravates following the intake of alcohol.

Clinical features of HL:

  • Painless enlargement of lymph nodes is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Cyclical fever (Pel–Ebstein fever) - cyclical increase, which then decreases over an average period of one or two weeks and night sweats in disseminated disease. This cyclical fever may be due to the release of cytokines.

A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.

questions.text: A patient died due to a stroke. Family members decide to donate the cadaver to the anatomy department of the medical college. During dissection of the cadaver, a resected specimen of the kidney appears as shown in the image below. What would be the likely disease that the patient has suffered from?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the gross specimen of a kidney showing small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface that gives a flea-bitten appearance to the kidneys, which is characteristically seen in malignant hypertension.

Pathophysiology of malignant hypertension 

  • Vascular damage (due to chronic hypertension, arthritis, and coagulopathy) increases the permeability of small vessels to fibrinogen and other plasma proteins.
  • This causes endothelial injury and platelet deposition, which causes fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Kidneys become ischemic, which stimulates the renin-angiotensin system to produce angiotensin II; angiotensin II, in turn, causes renal vasoconstriction as well as increased aldosterone secretion and salt retention, which elevate the blood pressure even further.
  • This may be related to increased TRPC3 expression in the vascular endothelium.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with dyspnea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient has a higher risk of developing:
questions.solution:
The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.

Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis. 

Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis. 

Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common monoclonal immunoglobulin seen in patients with myeloma?
questions.solution:
The most common monoclonal Ig (M protein) in myeloma is IgG (approximately 55% of patients), followed by IgA (approximately 25% of cases).

The immunosecretory disorders are a diverse group of diseases associated with the proliferation of an abnormal clone of immunoglobulin-synthesizing, terminally differentiated B cells. These disorders include:

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) and its variants
  • Plasmacytoma
  • Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
  • Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance
  • Monoclonal Ig deposition diseases - Includes primary amyloidosis and nonamyloidotic types.

The immunoglobulin can be complete or can be composed of either heavy or light chains and is termed M-(monoclonal) protein. Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 gm/dL of serum immunoglobulin. Myelomas expressing IgM, IgD, or IgE occur, but they are rare.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have excessive bleeding following tooth extraction. Lab investigations revealed prolonged aPTT, decreased serum factor VIII levels and normal VwF activity. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. Hence, it affects mainly males and homozygous females.

Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. 

Hemophilia C is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait.

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings will be seen in patients with chronic alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Chicken-wire fence pattern of fibrosis is seen in the liver biopsy of patients with alcoholic steatohepatitis. This pattern is due to perisinusoidal fibrosis encircling small clusters of hepatocytes. 

Trichrome staining of liver biopsy specimen showing perisinusoidal fibrosis (stained blue) in characteristic chicken-wire fence pattern is given below.

Note: Other conditions with chicken-wire pattern in histopathology:

  • Chicken wire calcification - chondroblastoma
  • Chicken wire vasculature - oligodendroglioma and myxoid liposarcoma

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image showing deposits in the kidney. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney which is suggestive of membranous nephropathy.

The following electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. It is due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

  • RPGN

MPGN: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

PSGN: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

questions.text: How would you classify the following according to the DeBakey classification?
questions.solution:
The above image shows proximal dissection of only the ascending aorta. This is classified as type II as per DeBakey's classification.

 Classification of aortic dissection:

  • Stanford Type A - proximal lesions. These are more common and dangerous. It may involve:
    • Both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey type I
    • Only the ascending aorta - DeBakey type II
  • Stanford Type B or DeBakey type III - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery

questions.text: In patients with acute graft-versus-host disease, which of the following organs is least likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The lung is least likely to get affected in acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically crippled recipients. The transferred cells recognize alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues.

It is seen most commonly in the setting of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation. Rarely, it may occur following transplantation of solid organs rich in lymphoid cells (e.g., the liver) or transfusion of unirradiated blood. 

It is of two types, acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD develops within days to weeks. There is the involvement of the immune system and epithelium of the skin, liver, and intestines. It presents with:

  • Generalized rash
  • Jaundice
  • Bloody diarrhea due to mucosal ulceration
  • Non-infectious pulmonary infiltrates (rarely), the outcome is generally poor

Chronic GVHD may follow the acute syndrome or occur insidiously. It presents with:

  • Skin - extensive cutaneous injury, with the destruction of skin appendages and dermal fibrosis (may resemble systemic sclerosis)
  • Liver - chronic liver disease, manifested as cholestatic jaundice
  • GIT - esophageal strictures
  • Immune system involvement - involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes

GVHD is mediated by T lymphocytes contained in the transplanted donor cells. Therefore, depletion of donor T cells before transfusion virtually eliminates the disease.

questions.text:
p-ANCA is positive in which of the following conditions?
  1. Ulcerative colitis
  2. Crohn's disease
  3. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  4. Churg–Strauss syndrome
  5. Microscopic polyangiitis
questions.solution:
Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the small vessels, not p-ANCA.

The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA):

  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome
  • Microscopic polyangiitis
Antibodies Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease
p-ANCA Present in majority (75%) Present in minority (11%)
Antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae Absent  Present

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining
